definition: duplicity/hypocrisy (idiom)
mouth/classifier for things with mouths (people, domestic animals, cannons, wells etc)/classifier for bites or mouthfuls
is/are/am/yes/to be
heart/mind/intention/center/core/CL:顆|颗[ke1],個|个[ge4]
abbr. for 非洲[Fei1 zhou1], Africa
to not be/not/wrong/incorrect/non-/un-/in-/to reproach or blame/(colloquial) to insist on/simply must

sentences.english: Woman's softheartedness, with man's hypocrisy, proportional to.
sentences.chinese: 女人的心慈手軟，與男人的口是心非，成正比。

sentences.english: Thomas Aquinas, following Aristotle. 67 It is not to be confused with timidity or fear, nor with duplicity or dissimulation.
sentences.chinese: 智德不和膽小或害怕，口是心非或虛僞相混。

sentences.english: It was no duplicity in order to increase rehabilitation.
sentences.chinese: 真是口是心非得無以復加。

sentences.english: A woman in addition to the fickle, also like duplicity.
sentences.chinese: 女人除了善變，還喜歡口是心非。

sentences.english: They speak vanity every one with his neighbor: with flattering lips and with a double heart do they speak.
sentences.chinese: 他們彼此說謊，用諂媚的嘴脣說話，口是心非。

sentences.english: Another accused him of his duplicity.
sentences.chinese: 另一家報紙指責他口是心非。

sentences.english: My words seem hypocritical, in fact sentence heartbreakers.
sentences.chinese: 我說的那些話貌似口是心非，其實句句撕心裂肺。

sentences.english: Why always say these unreliable of words?
sentences.chinese: 爲什麼總是說這些口是心非的話？

sentences.english: But she could not keep up the duplicity .
sentences.chinese: 但她無法一直口是心非地裝下去。

definition: heart and mouth at variance (idiom); keeping one's real intentions to oneself/saying one thing but meaning sth different
outside appearance and inner reality differ (idiom); not what it seems/saying one thing but meaning sth different
see 刀子嘴，豆腐心[dao1 zi5 zui3 , dou4 fu5 xin1]
to regard face as all-important/to consider loss of face unthinkable
small-minded/petty/narrow-minded
to say sth without meaning it (idiom); to speak tongue in cheek/saying one thing but meaning sth different
narrow-minded/petty
irony/ironic remark
lit. eats soft food, but refuses hard food (idiom)/amenable to coaxing but not coercion
false friendship/hypocritical show of affection
to imagine that one's love is reciprocated/to shower affection on an uninterested party
(idiom) sweet words/sweet talk/cajolery
false/hypocritical/artificial/sham
flippant and insincere (piece of writing or speech)/glib-tongued/oily
glib/oily-mouthed and smooth talking
to act stupid/to pretend to be naive
